key_insight: Treating context management as an explicit, callable tool (CAT) for LLM-based software-engineering agents enables proactive, semantic-aware pruning and organization of context, preventing context explosion and preserving reasoning quality over long-horizon interactions.
problem_solved: Existing SWE agents use append-only context or passive compression heuristics that cause context explosion, semantic drift, and degraded reasoning during long-running interactions with large code repositories.
method: Elevate context maintenance to a first-class tool with explicit operations (ingest, retrieve, summarize/compress, prune, and replace) that the agent can call during reasoning.
Use repository-aware indexing and semantic relevance scoring to prioritize and retain high-value context while applying targeted summarization and provenance-aware compression to older material.
Organize memory hierarchically (short-term working context + long-term archive) and apply policy-driven retention to avoid drift and maintain coherency across extended workflows.
impact: Makes LLM-driven software agents more scalable and reliable for long-horizon engineering tasks across large codebases, reducing error rates and cognitive overload from oversized contexts while improving end-to-end task performance and latency.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing agent ⇄ CAT tool ⇄ code repository, with explicit tool operations labeled (ingest/retrieve/compress/prune).
Before vs After timeline: append-only context growth and decline in reasoning quality vs CAT-managed stable context and sustained performance.
Bar/line chart of task success or accuracy vs interaction length comparing baseline (append-only) and CAT-managed agents.
Icon set showing key concepts: ‘tool’ icon for CAT, ‘archive’ for long-term memory, ‘filter/magnifier’ for relevance scoring, and ‘compress’ for summarization.
paper_title: Context as a Tool: Context Management for Long-Horizon SWE-Agents
paper_authors: Shukai Liu, Jian Yang, Bo Jiang, Yizhi Li, Jinyang Guo
